subject: Two Wins in One Day
event:
Life is magical and full of joy.

Somehow both of my teams won today.  The Giants defeated the Detroit Lions in the morning... just barely, admittedly, but a win is a win, and I'll take it.  And then somehow the Jets won as well, against a very good Pittsburgh Steeler team.  That one shocked even me.  I have never believed that the Jets were as bad as their record suggested and I figured they'd pull out of the tailspin and win one sooner or later, but I never expected it to be against the Steelers, supposedly the third best team in the AFC.  I'll take that one too, however.  The Jets D stepped up big, and Mangini took advantage of the bye week to install a number of nice new wrinkles and schemes.  

Of course, the hated Cowboys and despised Patriots both won huge, so the day wasn't perfect.

The G-Men look to be in pretty good position for a wild card, though they had several costly injuries today.  For four years in a row the Giants have been crippled by injuries in the second half of the season, one of the big factors in their late season collapses.  This year they have been relatively injury-free, so seeing Kiwi and Brandon go down produced deep forebodings.  I fear Kiwi is lost for the year, though I hope Jacobs can return soon.  If not, I hope Coughlin gives this kid Bradshaw some carries to spell Reuben Droughns.  He showed a lot of flashes in pre-season, and could have the makings of another Tiki Barber, if he can only learn to hold on to the ball.  I also wish Coughlin would sit down Plaxico Burress for a couple of games.  It's plain that his ankle is getting worse.  He's playing with pain and without practice.  Let him sit on the bench for two or three weeks and heal.  Go with Amani Toomer and Sinorice Moss, Steve Smith if he's healthy, and bring back that kid Anthony Mix.  Mix is raw, but has the size, and pretty good hands too.

As for the Jets... well, I don't expect they'll be able to stay with the hated Cowboys on Turkey Day, or with the despised Patriots later on, but they will probably win a few more before the season is done... just enough to make sure they don't get a top five draft pick.  Sigh.  Kellen Clemens showed promise today, Thomas Jones finally looked like the runner he was supposed to be, the O-line and D-line both played well... but Leon Washington won the game.  Amazing how the Steelers schemed to avoid kicking to Leon all game long, only to punt it straight at him in overtime, with the game on the line.  He made them pay.  Let's send Leon to the Pro Bowl...

comments.article: From "meaningless and has no purpose" to "magical and full of joy" in two days. :-)
I love that. So useful! I don't have to actually watch the games or look up scores. I just wait to see which phrase George uses, and I know who won. Saves me time and energy! :D

I went up from NC to Jersey and Philly to watch my Dolphins lose to the Eagles :(

but it was awesome and we were first row right in the corner of the end zone.

and I learned that real philly cheese steaks are even more awesome than I expected.
18" cheese steak with mushroom and bell peppers. Might kill ya, but you'll die happy.

The coaching staff lost the game for the Chiefs. Run Holmes for every first down and a draw play on every third and long. My husband was screaming for some different plays to be called. They just didn't trust the quarterback to be able to throw the ball.

If nothing else the wonderful title to this post is yet another example.

*lol*

I'm glad your day was better!
comments.subject: You're awesome!

comments.article: I know how you feel!  After a pretty rough season last year, the Packers are suddenly 9-1 so far in the regular season, their best start since 1962!  So, if the teams is comparing favorably to the salad days of Vince Lombardi, something must be right.

I'm glad life is no longer meaningless and without purpose...

Kellen Clemens was a joy to watch. Hope he finds success with your team.
My dad must be thrilled. Yesterday was his birthday.
comments.subject: oh yay

comments.article:
Steelers will have to go through growing pains with their new coach. As soon as Tomlin actually figures out how to, you know... coach, the Steelers should be pretty good.

Establishing the run simply because you feel it's your identity is pretty stupid when your QB has the second-ranked passer rating in the league and you're averaging 2.5 yard a rush against the team you're playing.

Life is meaningless and has no purpose.

My Steelers lost. How? They haven't let someone run 100 yards on them since the beginning of the '05 season. 34 games. And Thomas Jones does it?

The #1 rush offense faces the #30 rush defense, and we barely surpass 100 yards? And only 52 from Parker?

Our O-Line must have been asleep...allowing 7 sacks to a team that has only had 9 all year?

All of this and Donovan McNabb was on my fantasy team....
comments.subject: Grr..

comments.article: On the plus side George, you can rest easy knowing that the giants are probably going to be the ones to ruin the Pat's perfect Season. As a pats fan, I'd like to see them get it, even if Belichick is evil, but I just don't see them playing Brady vs that defense with no play off positioning on the line.

I'm sure this is something that the pro football fan hears again and again, but I just can't seem to find any joy in watching the NFL. I'm sure it's completely inconsistent with the rest of my entertainment views if I examine it, but it's just how I feel from my gut.
And this isn't just your typical doorstopper fantasy novel fan disliking sports thing, either (which I'm always surprised at the lack of posts stating that after Mr. Martin posts about football) - in fact, I enjoy college football. I'm not a raving fan by any stretch, but I sort of keep up with a few teams and watch it on the occasional lazy Saturday. I guess what keeps me from pro ball is my perceived lack of "heart" from the game itself. Everything is so commercial, it seems the coaches are ignored by players and the players themselves are traded around to the point I can't imagine anyone having any kind of team loyalty.
While I understand college ball has also become increasingly commercial, there has always seemed to me to be a certain core of something real in college ball that pro ball simply cannot have. That's very ambiguous, I know, but I just can't bring myself to care about something that the participants themselves don't care about.
No doubt that's inconsistent with my view about scripted entertainment like books and movies, which I do enjoy, but a movie never claims to be anything but what it is. With teams names and mascots and licensed gear, pro ball masquerades as something that it is not.
I know it is personal preference, and I am not trying to condemn anyone that likes pro ball, but I just can't get behind it.
Does anybody else feel like this? If not, why do you like pro football?
Discuss, discuss.
comments.subject: Pro Football

comments.article:
Basically, pro football distills what is best about the college game. Only the finest college athletes make it to the pro circuit, so play is faster and cleaner.

More to the point, though, every game in the pros is an actual game, whereas a good number on the college circuit are simply parades. Even a school with a "tough" schedule spends about a third of its season walloping creampuffs who can't recruit high-caliber talent. If you think about good college games, it's always between powerhouse schools who draw from the best talent pool. In the NFL, everyone has access to the same people, and thanks to the hard salary cap, everyone has the same financial chance to get them. That's why there's only one regular-season undefeated team in NFL history. There's one most years in college. (That said, this year's Patriots may be an exception)

Commercially, colleges make incredible amounts of money by earning spots in bowl games, which frequently involves running up the score on lesser opponents to increase their rankings. Of course, none of that money goes to the players who earn it, thanks to the NCAA, one of the most ruthless monopolies on the planet.

Lastly, loyalty. No player stays with a college for more than four years, by law. And you better believe that if a player feels his odds of getting NFL attention go up by transferring, he's gone before his sweat-towel dries. Also, coaches at big schools often have shorter tenures than in the NFL, and always get while the gettin's good. Witness Urban Meyer, given his big break by Utah, takes them to the Sugar Bowl, then promptly bails to move to Florida (personal bitterness there).

So, the college game is no bed of roses, the NCAA just does a good whitewashing job.
comments.subject: Re: Pro Football

comments.article:
I don't follow football (or anything else), with any avid regularity, I just have my home teams that I watch if I happen to catch them, and I'm good to go. (Arizona, yay!).

However, I love these posts, just because of the way football day is written up.

the Turkey day game presents the dreaded TRAP game for my BELOVED Dallas Cowboys. They play George's New York Jets in the afternoon game. After that, they are headed for a showdown with an old rival; Brett Favre and the Green Bay Packers.

Yah hey dare, how 'bout dem Packer, hey?

If both Dallas and Green Bay win on Thanksgiving (Green Bay plays Detroit in the early game) both will be 10-1 headed to a huge showdown at Texas Stadium on Thursday night, Novermber 29th on NFL Network. (huge court battle going on between NFL and cable right now because it will NOT be on regular tv as is right now!)THis game could have major playoff implications for homefield advantage. Green Bay is DAMED cold. Ice Bowl, anyone? Dallas has owned Favre in Texas stadium.

BUT all of this hype is moot...Dallas must play THIS Thursday first. Just like they had to play Buffalo the Monday night before they played the Evil Empire, the New England Patriots. That was the night Tony Romo threw FIVE interceptions and the Cowboys needed divine intervention to squeak out a victory in Buffalo on a last second field goal.

So...the New York Jets, fresh off their upset of the Steelers, make me quite nervous. Beware the trap, BELOVED Cowboys!!!!
comments.subject: the BIG trap!!

comments.article:
Trebla - Worry not. The Boys will beat the Jets by 17. In a way, I'm happy the Jets won yesterday - it gives Wade one more thing to stress these next few days ("If they beat the Steelers, they ain't pushovers...")

When our Boys play the Pats in January, who do you think grrm will be rooting for? The very idea of it is probably too horrible for him to imagine!
comments.subject: Re: the BIG trap!!

comments.upictitle: leading the revolution against reality: pic#105551635
comments.article:
hey now. the cowboys didn't win that big. we almost kicked their tushies....



sniff, sniff...wahhhhhh!
Gotta give it to Nuuuugg (Nugent),  his Buckeyes spank Michigan and he boots the winner!!!
comments.subject: Nugent

comments.article:
Being a Pats fan I don't get why every one hates the pats. :( I know it’s hard to root for a team who is winning. But it’s not like they are the Yankees who have a payroll 3-4 times larger then any other team. For some reason players are willing to take pay cuts to play for a ring.
Whatever :)

However I was very glad to see the GMen come back in that game, Maybe if Romo has a heart attack or TO explodes, they can get eliminated.

The "Hated" Cowboys got to stop teasing us, From now on I’m not going to watch their games till its in the 3rd or 4th. Every time I think they are on the verge of a collapse TO come up with a big play :-(... Every missed snap somehow becomes a 15 yard play... just not cool.

PS: I was also very happy that the Jets won, helping the pats get a higher round pick from the horrible 49rs (4rth pick overall as of now). Which they will trade for some lower ranked gems for less $$$.

It was also heart warming watching the treacherous Vinitery miss two more field goals and the trust of the Colts Offence coaching staff ( going for it on 4th and short … in the 4th seconds left … ouch … they wanted to give him Extra point distance before letting him kick anything) on Sunday.

Bah. Dallas barely beat the Redskins yesterday. We had them sweating bullets right up until the last second; the hurry-up offence works very well at confusing teams, Jason Campbell was as good as I've ever seen him (now that Al Saunders is starting to figure out that letting him off the leash is a good thing), and I've rarely seen our D as good as it was yesterday, holding Marion Barber and Julius Jones to very little yardage compared to their usual games. The only thing we really had wrong was a big Sean Taylor-shaped hole in the safety position; Priolieau tries, but he's just not up to par with Thug Owens. When Dallas comes to our house to play in December, we'll be ready.

Oh, and for anyone who tries to say that Dallas is the best team in the NFC, I have two words:

THE BILLS!

Well you had a better day than Chicago. Rex looked ok at best, our offensive line looked crappy, and Seattle kicked our wangs in.
Maybe I do know why you, an ex-Chicago resident, don't root for them.
Ah well. Go Bears still!!!
Also, Banewreaker and Godslayer were fantastic. Glad you recomended The Sundering.
-Justin
comments.subject: ugh...is it the QB or the offensive line?

comments.article:
You dig deep, each and every day
You take a hit on every play
You give the quarterback his time
To pad his stats and look sublime
You force the holes, for running backs
And forestall the dreaded sacks
You let your team control the clock
With each and every crucial block
Noone realizes what you do,
Save Belichik, Dungy, the chosen few,
Teams that have you, they win games,
Yet the fans don't even know your names
You rock, Offensive Line
comments.subject: On football: Ode to the O-line

comments.article:
Thats awsome,

PS: Matt Light :)
comments.subject: Re: On football: Ode to the O-line

comments.article:
Even though my Skins lost, I was still pleased with their performance against Dallas. We need to hold onto Campbell for a couple more years, and stop losing our key players.

Even though we didn't nail the Hail Mary, it was a hell of a pass, in my opinion.

As an aside, the bad snaps on Dallas's side had me giggling through the whole game. Especially the numerous replays of those bad snaps (I live in the DC area). Had to give them credit though, they were ace at picking them back up and making good plays with them. I hate admitting that, but it's true. Still made me laugh though.
I went to high school with Anthony Mix he was awesome then, I really hope he gets some game time.
comments.subject: I would love to see Mix play

comments.article:
Looks like you may get your wish... but not with the Giants.

A couple of days after my post, the Redskins signed Mix off the Giants' practice squad.

Maybe Joe Gibbs is reading my blog.
comments.subject: Re: I would love to see Mix play

comments.article:
The Giants' record this year...
Against teams that are now 9-1: 0-3
Against teams that are now 6-4 or 5-5: 3-0
Against teams that are now 2-8 or 0-10: 4-0

Make of that what you will. (I make of it that 7.5-2.5 is probably about right for them.)
At least you don't have to be a Saints fan. They have been so disappointing, then on a roll, and now disappointing yet again. It is horrible!
comments.subject: Grats on the wins

comments.article: no kidding.  go saints
comments.subject: Re: Grats on the wins

comments.article:
people hate the Pats now for the same reason people hate the cowboys (the reason i hate the cowboys) is that they are too good. i have been a pats fan since 91 and a giants fan as well. but i loath the cowboys and philly. As much as i love the pats, they will sooner or later fall from their perch and make room for the next dominant team that so many will hate because they are so good. as for the cheating issue, if you can say the pats are the only ones who do that, you need to add more paint chips to your wheaties. they just got caught. stupid for them to do at all....they paid...drop it. i wonder if the Giants were as dominant as the pats would you hate them? and if they had been caught cheating...would you spurn them?

the Giants and the Pats--THAT game is gonna be hard for me to watch
